page.title: 03Landscape of New Thundersley
page.content: { { {Hills }dominate the {landscape }being in the south east of the area. They rise to 78 metres and have a north westerly aspect over the shallow { {valley }of the River Crouch. The view is of low undulating land in central south east Essex. The{geology}of the hills is of Bagshot Sands and are underlain by thick, heavy London Clay. Numerous streams rise at the foot of the gravel and flow north into the Crouch. The gravel hills all have relatively flat summits, and can be seen from a great distance. The gradients of the slopes can be up to 15%. The surface drainage on the gravel is absent because the permeability of the rock; this has provided dry sites for settlement.
